First, can retrieve metadata separate repository: One file source repository contains invalid character Windows (:), ’ll need pull individually, rather cloning repository:

code: # since our texts are from speeches, # it might make sense to use the spoken norming context processed <- receptiviti(speeches$text, version = "v2", context = "spoken") processed <- cbind(speeches[, 1:4], processed)  kable(processed[1:5, -(1:7)], digits = 3, row.names = FALSE)

title: Commencement Example
text: get stylistic uniqueness, can calculate Language Style Matching speech mean speeches: , notable stylistically unique speech delivered American Sign Language, second stylistically unique speech short rhyme. might also want see speeches similar one another:
code: # Currently, the lingmatch package only automatically handles # `liwc.` prefixes, so we'll rename the `liwc15.` ones. colnames(processed) <- sub("liwc15", "liwc", colnames(processed), fixed = TRUE)  processed$lsm_mean <- lingmatch(processed, mean, type = "lsm")$sim  kable(processed[   order(processed$lsm_mean)[1:10],   c("name", "school", "year", "lsm_mean", "summary.word_count") ], digits = 3, row.names = FALSE) # calculate all pairwise comparisons lsm_pairs <- lingmatch(processed, type = "lsm", symmetrical = TRUE)$sim  # set self-matches to 0 diag(lsm_pairs) <- 0  # identify the closest match to each speech speeches$match <- max.col(lsm_pairs, "last") best_match <- lsm_pairs[   speeches$match + (seq_len(nrow(lsm_pairs)) - 1) * nrow(lsm_pairs) ]  # look at the top matches top_matches <- order(-best_match)[1:20] top_matches <- data.frame(a = top_matches, b = speeches[top_matches, "match"]) top_matches <- top_matches[!duplicated(apply(   top_matches, 1, function(pair) paste(sort(pair), collapse = "") )), ] kable(data.frame(   speeches[top_matches$a, 2:4],   Similarity = best_match[top_matches$a],   speeches[top_matches$b, 2:4],   check.names = FALSE ), digits = 3, row.names = FALSE)

(Note error bars represent much variance within groups, allows eyeball statistical significance mean differences.) shift emphasis power risk-reward reflect commencement speakers now focusing abstractly potential benefits hazards life graduation, whereas earlier speakers narrowly focused ambition dominance (perhaps referring power held past alumni projecting potential graduates climb social ladders future). examine sample speeches show pattern dramatically (speeches high risk-reward low power recent years, vice versa pre-2009 speeches) help determine themes shifted specific motives framing devices seem (de)emphasized.
code: library(splot)  # select drives categories drives <- processed[, grep("drives", colnames(processed), value = TRUE, fixed = TRUE)]  # identify those more correlated with time (excluding the few earliest cases) later_times <- processed$year > 1980 drives <- drives[, order(-abs(cor(   drives[later_times, ], processed$year[later_times] )))[1:3]]  splot(   drives ~ year, processed, year > 1980,   title = FALSE, laby = "Score", lpos = "top" ) time_median <- median(processed$year) processed$time_period <- paste(c("<", ">="), time_median)[   (processed$year >= time_median) + 1 ]  splot(   scale(drives) ~ time_period, processed,   title = FALSE, laby = "Score (Scaled)", lpos = "top" )

title: Commencement Example
text: SALLEE framework offers measures emotions, might see categories deviate segments: Now can look categories across segments:  bar chart displays original values, offers clearest view meaningful differences segments might , addition statistical significance (offers rough guide reliability differences, based variance within segments). looking bar graph, can immediately see admiration shows starkest differences middle early/late segments.  line charts, hand, shows standardized values, effectively zooming differences segments. clearly shows, example, admiration joy seem used bookends commencement speeches, peaking early late, whereas negative intense emotions anger, disgust, surprise peak middle section.
code: # select the narrower SALLEE categories emotions <- segmented_text[, grep("^sallee", colnames(segmented_text))[-(1:6)]]  # make contrasts for each segment contrasts <- matrix(   rep_len(c(1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1), nrow(segmented_text) * 3),   ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE )  # correlate emotion scores with contrasts segment_deviations <- abs(cor(emotions, contrasts))  # select the 5 most deviating emotions most_deviating <- segmented_text[, names(sort(-apply(   segment_deviations, 1, max ))[1:5])] splot(   most_deviating ~ segment, segmented_text,   laby = "Score", title = FALSE, mv.as.x = TRUE, type = "bar" ) splot(   scale(most_deviating) ~ segment, segmented_text,   leg = "out", laby = "Score (Scaled)", title = FALSE, prat = c(4, 1) )

text: Makes requests Receptiviti API, working around size rate limitations. Avoids sending invalid identical texts, repeating requests session. Optionally builds local database returned results avoid making repeat requests longer-term.
